Literature Review: Serine is a non-essential amino acid that plays a crucial role in various metabolic pathways, including carbohydrate metabolism, transamination, glycine, and folate-mediated one-carbon metabolism. The regulation of serine levels is essential for maintaining proper cellular function, and dysregulation of serine metabolism has been implicated in various diseases, including neuropathy, retinopathy, and cancer (1, 2). The central role of serine in metabolism is reflected in its involvement in the synthesis of glycine, which is a precursor for creatine, glutathione, and purines (3). Furthermore, serine is a key player in the one-carbon metabolism pathway, where it is converted to 5-methylthioadenosine, a precursor for methionine and homocysteine (4). The liver and kidney are the primary sites of serine metabolism, where it is converted to 3-phosphoglycerate, which can be used to produce energy or synthesize glycine (5). In the brain, serine is produced locally through the decarboxylation of pyruvate by the enzyme pyruvate decarboxylase (6). The regulation of serine levels is tightly controlled by a network of enzymes, including serine hydroxymethyltransferase, which catalyzes the conversion of serine to 5-methylthioadenosine (7). Abnormalities in serine metabolism have been implicated in various diseases, including diabetes, where impaired serine uptake and utilization contribute to insulin resistance and beta-cell dysfunction (8). In addition, serine dysregulation has been linked to the development of neuropathy, where impaired serine synthesis and disposal contribute to the progression of sensory neuropathy (9). The role of serine in retinopathy has also been explored, where impaired serine metabolism contributes to the development of retinal damage and vision loss (10). In cancer, serine dysregulation has been implicated in tumor growth and progression, where impaired serine synthesis and disposal contribute to the development of cancer (11). Dietary interventions in preclinical models have shown that modulating serine levels can have a significant impact on disease progression, including sensory neuropathy, retinopathy, tumor growth, and muscle regeneration (12). A serine tolerance test may provide a quantitative readout of serine homeostasis that identifies patients who may be susceptible to neuropathy or responsive to therapy (13). In conclusion, serine is a critical amino acid that plays a central role in various metabolic pathways, and dysregulation of serine metabolism has been implicated in various diseases. Further research is needed to fully understand the role of serine in human health and disease.
